cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.p: Le marché a présenté 1a méme aspect que la semaine passée, c’est-a-dire sans animation et avec unchiffre d’affairesexcessivement restreint. A part quelques échanges insignifiants et clair-. semés en Comptoir, Delta Land et quelques / autres valeurs, on n’a traité quela Khédivial Mail qui a été offerte sur le marché par milliers. Les ordres de venteprovenaient principalement da Caire. Cependant; comme il s’est trouvé des acheteurs pour absorber toutes les offres, le prix, apres avoir fiéchi de ‘1 shelling, est re- montéen cléture 4 20/6 acheteurs, soit en dé- finitive une perte de 6 pence en tout:pour la séance.
La Delta Land, la New-Egyptian, }’Aboukir, la Port Said Salt et la Salt & Soda étaient oftertes.

Quant aux titres dirigeants, ils ont été négli- gés, comme cela ressort de:leur cotation 4 des prix légtrement — inférieurs A ceux de vendredi passé. C’estainsi que l’Agricole rétrograde de, 77/8 a 718/16, la National Bank de 20 1/4 a 20 3/16 et.la Delta Light de 9 3/4 a 9 11/16, T’Obligation Crédit Foncier fiéchit’ aussi de 287.4285 1/2 V’ancienne et de 2524251 1/2 la nonvelle, mais ces nouveaux cours s enten- dant ex-tirage, il n’y a pas de baisse propre- ment dite.
L’ Alexandria Water recule de 10.7/8 a 10 3/4 ex-coupon, la Banque d’Athénes de 118 1/2 4 113, la Privilégiée Khedivial Mail de 4 1/4a 4 1,8, et la Banque d’Orient de 1123/4 & 112.

Parmi les titres de moindre envergure, .la Salt & Soda. tombe de 14/3 a 14/-, les Sucre- ries de 34 4 33, le Comptoir de 27/16 4 2 3/8, l’Aboukir de 28/9 a 28/-, Ja Port Said Salt de 12/3 & 12/-, la Fanous dé 5/16 a 9/82, ainsi a la Levico. L’Urbaine remonte de 3 1/8 a 3 3/16
Ila été vendu aux enchéres publiques a6 Comptoir Financier et Commercial d’Egypte a 2 13/32 et 19 Obligations, Crédit Foncier Egyp- tien dont 17 nouvelles 4 252 et 2 anciénnes & 290 1/2.

En vue d’éviter de nouveaux frais d’admi- nistration, un groupe de porteurs de parts Société Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh de- mande au conseil d’administrafion de «porter & l’ordre du jour de la prochaine assemblée générale annuellé la question de la liquidation | et répartition de l’actif existant. Une pétition dans ce sens, couverte de signatures, va étre -expédiée 4 S.S8. Harari Pacha . qu’on propose comme liquidateur. Une demande analogue ‘avait déja été formalée l'année derniére, mais n’ayant pas été faite dans les délais prescrits | ® par les statuts, elle avait été rejutée.

Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.

div.head: THE PERSIAN PARLAMENT.
div.p: Teheran, December 15. The Cabinet resigned yesterday in conse- quence of incidents arising ont ofthe murder of two shop keepers by soldiers, who were im- prisoned bat whose immediats execution was demanded by the relatives of the victims and the Anjumans. A great crowd, partly armed, assembled near the Parliament buildings. The bazaars were closed and ball cartridges were served out tothe Palace quards and garrison The Shah summoned Nizam Sultaneh and Nizam el Malk.

(Later). Parliament has been informed that the ex-Premier and ex-Minister of the Interior have been arrested by order of the Shah The House has demanded an explanation from the Sovereign, refusing to quit the building before & reply was received. The crowd is also wait- ing. It is believed that the Shah is acting on the advice of the reactionary members ( Reuter)

div.head: SOUTH AFRICAN SITUATION.
div.p: DurBan, December 14. Dini Zulu has started for Durban. Colonel Mackenzie’s troops have returned to Nongoma after marching throngh the disaffect- ed areas. They discovered a number of young Usutu tribesmen with rifles who were missing. (Reuter)
Durpan, December 15. Ten of the principal natives accompanying Dini Zulu have been arrested on suspicion of sedition. (Reuter)

div.head: PUNISHMENT OF THE BENI-SN ASSENS.
div.p: Marnia, December 14. A Jarge column has left to punish the Beni- Snassens.. ~* , (Havas) Oran, December 15. A French column 3,000 strong has moved out of Lalaparmania, operating against the Snassen tribesmen who are posted in the hills, (Reuter)

div.head: CONTRABAND ARMS
div.p: MOROCCO. Tanargr, December 14. Abd el Aziz has given France and Spain the orderto repress contraband of arms in Moroc- an waters, (Havas) T'anarer, December 15. M. Regnault has returned. (Havas)

div.head: MASSACRE OF ALBANTANS.
div.p: SALONIKA, December 15. 2,000 Montenegrins have crossed the frontier near Gusinie and massacred the inhabitants of two Albanian villages. ( Reuter)

div.head: DEVELOPMENTS we PENLAND.
div.p: Sr. Peressnvat Deesibber 15. Important developments are imminent in Finland. General Kaulbars, ex-Governor of Odessa, will be appointed Governor-General and a strong military force is proceeding there, ostensibly for manwuyres. The Government is apparently resolved to crush the revolutionary, organisations. (Reuter)

div.head: AUSTRALIAN ‘TEST MATCH.
div.p: Sypney, December 14. Cricket. At lurich time Australia’s score was os runs for 2 wickets. (Reuter) Sypyry, December 14. Cricket Australia 300. England second in- (Reuter)

div.head: AUSTRIA AND "MACEDONIA.
div.p: AN IMPORTANT INTERVIEW. Vrewna, December 14. In political cireles great importance is at- tached to the interview to take place to-day between Baron Marshall @nd Baron d’Aeren- thal concerning Macedonia judiciary question. The Prince of Bulgarie has. visited Baron d’Aerenthal, (Havas)

div.head: PLAGUE AT ORLEANSVILLE.
div.p: hisses: ILLE, December 14, Trp cases of plague have been notified here. ( a ee STORMS IN FRANCE. Paris, December. 14. Violent storms throughéut France are re ported. (Havas) DIJON SENATORIAL ELECT CTION. ae Deceuker 15. Senatorial election. Philipot, Republican, has been elected, beating André. (Havas)

div.head: ANTI-DUELLING LEAGUE.
div.p: KING VICTOR PATRON; | Romer, December 15. The King has become patron of the Italian Anti-Duelling League. (Reuter)

div.head: Headaches and Neuralgia.
div.p: THE EFFICACY OF DR. WILLIAMS’ PINK PILLS.

Mme Octave Mignolet, whose portrait is given herewith, lives in the Rue Longue, Ostend. She suffered trom a variety of ailments, and particularly sick headaches and acute neafalgia, Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills for Pale People had an excellent effect on her nervous system, and now she has ceased to suffer from neuralgia and headaches, and enjoys splendid health.

“I was always in pain,” she writes, “and there never was a night when I could look back and say that I had passed a pleasant day. I was out of gorts and not at all strong. What | ~. ra "| fatiened me more than anything else were sick headaches, which I had almost every day, while sometimes I had neuralgia for weeks at a stretch. My life became insupportable, for I could scarcely get a moment's sleep. I resorted to all sorts of devices to get some rest, but my neuralgia was an obstacle to all my efforts, and the nights passed without my having slept atall Of course, I tried many medicines, but none of them did me any good, until I gave Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills a trial, having.read of their efficacy ina newspaper. These pills cured me, ahd my existence is now quite changed.” The prediliction for sick headaches in the weaker sex is proverbial. Headaches are due to stomech disorder, and when they occur frequently, it is a sign of anemia. It is the ‘|. same with neuralgia, thé continuance of which

div.head: COTTON IN. THE LEVANT.
div.p: Beyrouth, 9th December. The publication by Reuter’s Agency of the} important intelligence of the final conclusion of details of the Konia Irrigation Scheme has brought once more Asia Minor with its _poli- tical and vast economic possibilities, before the eyes of Europe and will continue to be the chief subject of discussion and comment. A few particulars therefore about the present agricultaral and industrial activities of the outlying regions such as Mersine and’ Adana may not be devoid of particular interest. In a former article ample reference was made to the recent introduction of the perfected methods of steamploughing in connection particularly with cotton cultivation and the following com- plementary notes appear to be necessary. The area under cotton cultivation in Mersine and Adana districts is estimated at about 170,000 acres and the yield ranges between forty and fifty thousand bales of 200 kilogrammes the bale. The Germans seem to have had a long time ago their eye on the cotton culture with its vast possibilities of development and it was German capital that built the first factory for ginning crude cotton and the pressing of bales according tothe system adopted in Egypt. Bales of 250 kilogrammes pressed at this factory have a much smaller volume than bales of 200 kilos, ordinarily pressed, The resulting economy in freight is obvious ‘Thanks to German initiative also the seed of ‘the American ‘quality known as “Upland” and which is in special demand in the New Orleans markets has been introduced first as a trial and is since being gradually vulgarized considering the eminently satisfactory results In the direction of the development of agri- cultural methods on modern lines the English | sales have the largest share of initiative, and most ‘if not all of the various implements lately introduced have come and still come from English firms, notably that of Messrs. John Fowler and Co. Ltd. at Leeds. There are‘ now in use six steamplonghs of which two with single traction and four with double traction, several orders are on the way. There are also 60 thrashing machines, and every year fairly important additions to the existing stock are made. As regards reaping machines they may be counted by hundreds and indeed their use is universal save in the mountainons parts where the primitive scythe still’survives. —

But the field for gigantic enterprise is left for the Germans, and the pent up activity of | . this eminently scientific and industrious nation is destined to manifest itself ina magnificent manner and restore that virgin country to its old glory, with. the additional blessings of modern civilization, when it is likely to become a great centre of productiveness that will count as a factor in the world’s economic problem. The Baghdad railway, a grandiose scheme, is being slowly elaborated and step by step it is nearing the great though distant goal. The Mersine Tarsus Adana Line which is $7 kilo- meters in length has already been bought up by the Germans and two shipments of about 1200 tons of, iron sleepers have lately been discharged by the German Atlas steamers of Bremen, to replace the old and worn out material. This small line is destined to be ultimately linked with the grand trank line which has passed already Eregli and reached Bourgulu which lies within only 160 kilometers of Mersine.

This junction which seems to be inevitable will be either at Adana or Mersine. In the first case the Baghded trunk line will it is said have to pass by Koulek Boughaz round the base of the intervening chain of mountains | and passing the valley join the M.T.A. line at Adana. In the second case the Baghdad line will have to cross the Pass of Dunkelek and join the M.T.A. line at Mersine. In either indicates organic Conkle and poverty of the blood, Dr Willian’ Pick Pills for Pale People| © have a full assortment of ereate rich and pure blood with every dose ;} neW and fashionable goods for the they tonify the nervous system ; and they are| . sovereign against anemia, chlorosis: general season. debility, stomach ills, rheumatism, sick head- aches, and neuralgia.

case the Taurus will have to be traversed and it is here that the greatest material obstacle in the way of the grand scheme lies. The Koulek Boughaz route involves the construction of fewer tunnels but presents on the other hand difficulty of crossing large marshy tracts. The Dunbelek route while involving more costly and difficult tan has the advantage of avoiding these tracts. The plan favoured-by the Turkish Govern. nent would cause the line to pass by Konlek | Boughaz following mére or less closely the actual carriage road which meets the Mersine Tarsous Adana line at Tarsous. The Anatolian Railway. Company. however” prefers. another | Sosa plan lying more in an easterly direction and us A ee ealoulated to bamuch shorter and less costly. , ae The trunk line in that case would follow the valley of Bozant descending through the valley an of Tchakit-Déré directly to Adana. In any case the Koulek Boughaz route would term in- ae other ieee are as Follows :— Ke Sa vy: eee or _—_ ol Mageaby “cana, RuoCherf Pacha, ALEXANDRIA, aleo at ate at Tarsous or rather at the station of Koulek Boughaz about 6 kilometers East of Tarsous and not at Mersine, © Apart from the p0litical interest attaching tothe Baghdad Railway the economic side thereof has incalculable importance, more so as it is bound up with the great Mesopotamian irrigation scheme. The niost indifferent cannot fail to watch with interest” the evdlution of this colossal scheme and we can only hope that the two great sister nations will ultimately find means of conciliating their political and econo- mic interests, and once an agreement is come to, the greatest of modern achievements will unfold themselves to the eyes of the word.

div.head: U.S. A. AND EGYPT.
div.p: A New York Coitmercial N ewspaper Says :— Otir part in Egypt’s import trade is lament- ably small. Int1906, according to “Daily Con- sular and Trade Reports, that country’s im-| ports amounted to $116,596,715, and our share was only $3,042,275, though we bought $7,660,900 worth of Egyptian goods. Oar chief were : machinery, $256,520; timber, $134,050; wronght iron and steel, $45,988, and a miscellanabus. list’ of smaller items, In the year our sales increased by $609,400 over 1905, chiefly in coffee, petroledm and fertilisers. Egypt's exports in 1906 amounted to $124,336,400. For our $7,660,900 we got cotton ($7,376,870), cereals, dried roots, hides and skins,rags and paper, sugar and gum arabic, in’ small consignments. In August, 1906, a Cairo dealer in American. oe furniture ordered some articles from the United neous Cricket & Foot Be a 1G States and sent four-fifths cash with the order, oe but in April, 1907, he was still without. the Boxing | oods. Export trade cann be built up in that way.

Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.

div.head: Winter Clothing.
div.p: We have a full assortment of new and fashionable goods for the season.

Our stock in this department is the largest in Egypt. We show the newest and best cloths that can be brought and sell them at London prices. Our Cutters are the best in Egypt and we guarantee a perfect fit.

The Universal Remedy for Acidity of the Stomach, Headache, Heartburn, Indigestion,
Sour Eructations, Bilious Affections.

Safesta and most Gentle Medicine for Infants, Children, Delicate Females, and the
Sickness of Pregnancy.

div.head: Dr. Le Clerc's Pills
div.p: Are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel, pains in the back and kindred ailments (aquired or constitutional). sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 2d. bearing the British Governemnt Stamp with the words Eugene Le Clere, impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommmended by eminent dermatologists in the treatment of eczema, lepra, psoriadis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infections disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimise the inconvenciences of shaving in cases of pimples, spota, teosone. In Tbalets, price is sold by Max Fischer, Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: W. H. ALLEN, Son & Co., Ltd.
div.p: Makers of the well-known “CONQUEROR” and Centrifugal Pump & Pumping Engines; also of Dynamos and High-Speed Economical Steam-Engines.
A large assortment of our pumps are kept in stock by our Agents, The Midland Engineering Co. of Rue de la Gare du Caire, No. 2, Alexandria.

Large stocks of rails, trucks and locomotives always kept in Alexandria.

Steam engines, Boilers, complete installations for Factories.

PER DAY

div.head: Telephone Company of Egypt, Limited.
div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.

PUBLIC CALL-OFFICES : Cairo, Central Office, Opera Square, and New Bar; Helouan, Central Office, Maison Purvis ; Alexandria, St Mark’s Buildings, Egyptian Bar, I. Castelli & Co.; Ramleh, Central Office. San Stefano Casino 30.4.907

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p:
Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the
Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the
Company andover 100 principal stations of the State
Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from
or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for
public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government
Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and
information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah
or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
